clinical_study.brief_title: Interleukin-1A, Interleukin-1B and Vitamin D Receptor Gene Polymorphisms in Periodontitis
clinical_study.official_title: Interleukin-1A rs1800587, Interleukin-1B rs1143634 and Vitamin D Receptor rs731236 Gene Polymorphisms in Stage III Grade B/C Periodontitis

brief_summary.textblock:
Background: The aim of the study is to find out the prevelance of IL1A (rs1800587), IL1B (rs1143634) and VDR (rs731236) gene polymorphisms in Turkish population and their association with stage III grade B / C periodontitis.
Methods: Individuals who were found to be systemically and periodontally healthy (N = 100) after clinical and radiographic examination and who were diagnosed with Stage III Grade B / C periodontitis (N = 100) were included in the study. Plaque index, gingival index, bleeding on probing, pocket depth and clinical attachment levels of the patients were recorded. Genotyping of IL1A (rs1800587), IL1B (rs1143634) and VDR (rs731236) gene polymorphisms was performed by Real Time Polymerase Chain Reaction.

detailed_description.textblock:
A total of 200 healthy or patients were recruited from the Clinics of Periodontology.
Periodontal clinical parameters such as plaque index, gingival index, probing depth and clinical attachment level were assessed. Genotyping of IL1A (rs1800587), IL1B (rs1143634) and VDR (rs731236) gene polymorphisms was performed by Real Time Polymerase Chain Reaction.Statistical analysis was performed using the statistical software package SPSS v16. SNPassoc.

arm_group.description: Patients with stage III, grade B / C periodontitis were diagnosed based on the new classification criteria. [2, 24] Clinical attachment loss ≥5 mm, probing depth (PD) ≥6 mm, ≥20 teeth and radiographic bone loss extending to the middle third of the root. Grade B was evaluated indirectly considering radiographic bone loss in the most affected tooth in the dentition as a function of age (0.25-1.0). Grade C was assessed considering the radiographic bone loss in the most affected tooth in the dentition as a function of age (>1.0).

The periodontally healthy subjects without any clinical sign of inflammation,not showing a history of periodontitis; PD ≤3 mm; <10% of sites with bleeding on probing (BOP); an absence of detectable attachment and/or bone loss; without extensive caries or restorations and presence of at least 28 permanent teeth. In addition, all the control subjects showed the absence of any local or systemic pathology.

study_pop.textblock: total of 200 subjects were recruited from the Clinics of Periodontology, Faculty of Dentistry, Marmara University

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
systemically healthy, previously untreated periodontitis patients
Exclusion Criteria:
presence of systemic disease such as diabetes, rheumatic fever, liver or kidney diseases, neurologic deficiencies, immunologic diseases; pregnancy; smoking (current and past); use of any medication which may affect periodontal tissues (phenytoin, cyclosporine, nifedipine, chronic use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, etc.); received antibiotics for any purpose within 6 months.

facility.name: Marmara University Dental Faculty Periodontology Department
